newsitem.title: UK: UK match-rigging jury dismissed without verdict.
newsitem.headline: UK match-rigging jury dismissed without verdict.

text.p: The jury in the trial of top English-based footballers Bruce Grobbelaar, Hans Segers and John Fashanu on charges of match-fixing was discharged on Tuesday when it failed to reach a verdict, Sky Television said.

Former Liverpool goalkeeper Grobbelaar, former Wimbledon keeper Segers, former Aston Villa striker Fashanu and Malaysian businessman Heng Suan Lim had all pleaded not guilty to conspiring to influence English premier league soccer matches.
Prosecuting counsel David Calvert-Smith said the crown wanted a retrial but the final decision would have to be taken "at the highest level".

"My lord, in these cases it is normal for the prosecution to press for a fresh trial with a new jury. That is the Crown's current intention," he told the judge. Earlier on Tuesday, judge Simon Tuckey, had told the jury he would accept a majority verdict at the end of the seven-week trial.
But the foreman of the jury handed a note to Tuckey in mid-afternoon saying they were unable to reach either a unanimous or a majority verdict and were unlikely to do so.
The judge then discharged the jury.
